entry.title: Re: Output Management - How to send emails to mail-addres...
entry.content:
Hello @SCHNEIDERT 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the information you provided and from my understanding, the Cloud V2 only shows contact email from the Account Contact relationship. The Output Management on the other hand normally reads email from the BP address, so basically there is a mismatch.

My suggestion is to add a logic because there is not standard customization that changes Output Management. Therefore, enabling BAdI APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS in Output Parameter Determination and implementing the BAdI to read the relationship-based email (through a CDS view on BP relationships and addresses) and return it as the email recipient should provide the solution. Doing it this way will help you keep a single source of truth and still use Output Management without changing standard integration behaviour

See the following for more information: 3331087 - Sample implementations of custom logic: Addition of Email Recipients - SAP S/4HANA Cloud

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Question of Full Loading Large CDS VIews from S/4 HANA: Problems and Solutions
entry.content:
Introduction

It‚Äôs no secret that many companies today have large, or even massive, datasets in S/4 HANA systems that need to be uploaded to SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere or SLT. A prime example of this is the CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData, which consume data from the ACDOCA table. There are known cases where the ACDOCA table exceeds 10 billion records. This article will discuss the problems that arise when transferring such large datasets and explore potential solutions.

In my previous article, I mentioned that the first step in the initial data load procedure is the calculation of "Access Plans". This is necessary to speed up the data loading process by parallelizing the processes. Each access plan is a specific range of records, defined by the object‚Äôs key fields. The size of this range is set during start of replication and varies for different scenarios. For example, in a BDC scenario, the default size of a single portion is 500 megabytes, for SAP Datasphere Replication Flows size portion is 30 megabytes. Since one access plan consists of 100 portions, the size of an access plan is approximately 50 gigabytes for BDC scenario and 3 gigabytes for Replication Flows. 

Note: above mentioned size is the size of data representation in ABAP runtime.

The Access Plan Calculation process itself consists of two phases: pre-calculation (aka delimitation) and calculation of access plans. The pre-calculation process divides the entire dataset into large chunks, which are known as "access plans". The calculation process reads the data within the calculated boundaries, divides it into portions, and writes these portions to a special intermediate buffer. Immediately after the calculation of one access plan is complete, a transfer process for that access plan is initiated. Optimization in  the access plan calculation process is achieved because, after the pre-calculation phase, each access plan is calculated in a separate process, and the number of these processes is limited only by service settings, system power, and allocated computing resources.

The main problem for very large CDS Views arises during the pre-calculation process. During pre-calculation, the process reads all sorted key fields of all records from the CDS View once to determine the boundaries of the access plans. This is where problems can occur due to the limitations imposed by the HANA database. There are several limitations:

- First, HANA DB imposes a limit on the number of records returned in a single query ‚Äì it cannot exceed 2 billion records.
- Second, there is a parameter that defines the memory size allocated by HANA DB for a single session. The query can exceed the memory allocated for one session.
- Third, overflow can also occur if HANA DB does not build query plans optimally enough.
In such cases, the object gets stuck in the "Error in Delimitation Process" status, which you can observe in the DHADM tool, in the "Access Plan Calculation Overview" section. In this case, you need to choose the optimal solution strategy and restart the object upload.

So, what solutions are available to address these problems? First, I will briefly list them, and then I will describe each approach in more detail:

  1. If a session runs out of memory, the simplest and most obvious solution is to increase the session memory limit provided to each session.
  2. If the CDS View contains simple left outer join or simple select from a table with more than 2 billion records, then database partitions are used during pre-calculation process.
  3. If the main table of the CDS View is partitioned, it may be possible to use special hints that will help HANA DB build query plans efficiently.
  4. If previous recommendations do not help, it is suggested to use the ranges functionality, provided in DHADM tool.

Unfortunately, there is no universal solution to these problems; each option has its pros and cons, involves certain complexities in implementation, and has some limitations. You must independently decide which approach will be the most optimal for a given dataset to solve the problem.

 

1. Increasing the Session Memory Limit Size in HANA DB

The official documentation on the SAP Help Portal contains detailed information on "Setting a Memory Limit for SQL Statements": 
On the portal, you will find recommendations for the allocated memory sizes and how to change the parameter value.
 
However, it should be kept in mind that increasing the session memory limit can only help if the number of records in the CDS View does not exceed 2 billion records.
Although this method helps in most cases, it's still has limits, it may have to be combined with the solution described below.
 
Practical Example:
The buffer size was set to 341 GB. And although, according to expert assessment by HANA DB specialists, this value is very large, this size was still not sufficient to execute the query from the I_GLAccountLineItemRawData CDS View.
It is potentially possible to continue increasing the parameter value further, but it is still recommended to look for other ways to solve the problem.
 

2. Utilizing Physical Partitioning of the Main Table at the HANA DB Level

This option provides a solution when the CDS View contains more than 2 billion records. Usually, such CDS View is built on partitioned table. Using physical partitioning the pre-calculation process divides the table into large blocks. 
The calculation of Access Plans will be performed within each partition separately, independently of each other. By the way, in this case, the pre-calculation process will also be accelerated because it is performed in several parallel processes.

Picture 1. Access plan calculation concept

Please note that pre-calculation will only use the partitions created for the main table. The role of the main table must be described in the dataExtraction annotation within the CDS View or can be determined automatically in simple cases. Example CDS View: I_GLAccountLineItemRawData:

      dataExtraction: {
        enabled: true,
        delta.changeDataCapture: {
          mapping:
            [
              {
                table: 'ACDOCA',
                role: #MAIN,
                viewElement: ['SourceLedger', 'CompanyCode', 'FiscalYear', 'AccountingDocument', 'LedgerGLLineItem'],
                tableElement: ['rldnr', 'rbukrs', 'gjahr', 'belnr', 'docln']
              }
            ]
         }
      }

Code 1. Example of CDS Annotation with declaration of MAIN table


For example, for the ACDOCA table, there is SAP Note 2289491, which provides best practice recommendations.

Nevertheless, there are examples where this does not help, and the error persists. In this case, you can try supplementing the solution with the first option (increasing buffer) and/or the next option using DB hints.

 

3. Utilizing HANA DB Hints

 
If you are the owner of the CDS View (and have control over the code), you can use HANA recommendations and apply database hints directly in CDS View to help the database build query plans more efficiently. Or you can apply hint to existing SQL statement.
 
@Consumption.dbHints: ['USE_HEX_PLAN']
An article from the official SAP Help Portal containing detailed information on "Performance Aspects of Specific Features" where you can find a description of the hint.
 
This method is recommended to be used in conjunction with table partitioning. This can help save memory and stay within the allocated buffer for a single session.
 
 
Practical Example:
In continuation of the first practical example, it's not possible to apply a hint to the SAP owned CDS View which cannot be changed.
In such case it is necessary to find the hash value of pre-calculation query (for example, using the search in DBACOCKPIT->Performance->Expensive Statements). The pre-calculation statement looks like:
 
SELECT /* Contains Native SQL */ "SOURCELEDGER" , "COMPANYCODE" , "FISCALYEAR" , "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" FROM /* Entity name: I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA WITH PRIVILEGED ACCESS */ "IFIGLACCTLIR" "A" WHERE "MANDT" = ? AND "FISCALYEAR" = ? AND EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM "ACDOCA" PARTITION (10) WHERE "ACDOCA" . "RCLNT" = ? AND "ACDOCA" . "RLDNR" = "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" AND "ACDOCA" . "RBUKRS" = "A" . "COMPANYCODE" AND "ACDOCA" . "GJAHR" = "A" . "FISCALYEAR" AND "ACDOCA" . "BELNR" = "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" AND "ACDOCA" . "DOCLN" = "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM" ) ORDER BY "A" . "SOURCELEDGER" , "A" . "COMPANYCODE" , "A" . "FISCALYEAR" , "A" . "ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENT" , "A" . "LEDGERGLLINEITEM"
 
And execute the following command:,
 
ALTER SYSTEM ADD STATEMENT HINT ( USE_HEX_PLAN ) FOR STATEMENT HASH '2e23331ec91cbc6b803aa477ec4538d9';
 

4. Usage of Range Conditions Functionality

Even so, it may happen that all the previously described methods do not solve the problem. There is another method, which is very similar to partitioning - Range Conditions in DHADM transaction.

Ranges are the division of the entire dataset into parts, same to database partitions, but it is performed only for pre-calculation during initial load process. The advantages of this approach are:

- Ranges can be defined independent from database partitions.
- Ranges can break down data into smaller portions than partitions.
- When using ranges, the SQL query has a simpler form, and HANA DB significantly optimizes this type of query.
Here, I want to describe several questions that arise when using Range Conditions.

a. Are Range Conditions applied only during Initial Load?
Yes, ranges are applied and used only for the initial snapshot load. During the delta phase, ranges no longer play any role.

b. Is it possible to use Range Conditions for data filtering?
Yes, it is possible, but strongly not recommended.
First, based on the previous point - filters based on ranges will only be applied for the initial load. Delta data will not be filtered. And secondly, you must always remember that the ranges are defined the in scope of current client and CDS View. This means that if you want to load the same CDS View with different "filters", you will not be able to. The same set of "filters" will always be used. To filter data, it is recommended to use the mechanisms provided by various scenarios. For example, SLT and Datasphere offer the ability to defined filters when setup replication. The BDC scenario does not provide filter capability.

c. What operations are supported in the definition of range conditions?
All standard logical comparison operations, as well as AND/OR and BETWEEN.
Do not forget to define ranges correctly, especially open boundary range conditions. There should be no gaps in the definition. It is recommended to make the boundary intervals open to avoid data loss. For example:

 interval 1: key1 < 1000
 interval 2: 1000 <= key1 < 5000
  ...
 interval N: key1 >= 100,000

Code 2. Example of range boundaries

During save Range conditions will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user. 

d. Who should define and maintain ranges, and what is the optimal strategy in defining ranges?
We cannot give you any particular recommendation how to define range conditions. Each client independently defines the ranges according to their needs and data content.
Analyze your data structure, look at which key fields do not change very often so that you can use them as a basis for dividing the data, and see how evenly the data is distributed across these values.
By the way, in the first option, you can use the same conditions that are proposed for database partitioning. Since, as already mentioned, another simplified form of the SQL query is used for ranges, there is a possibility that these ranges will solve the problem.

e. How to create Range conditions?
One of the drawbacks is that ranges must be defined manually, range by range, using the DHADM UI.

Add new range via DHADM UI

Picture 2. How to add new Range manually via DHADM UI

However, by installing SAP Note 3670148, a simpler way to support ranges is offered, which also allows you to migrate ranges between systems.

You need to create an file with the specific structure. The file‚Äôs structure should follow the specifications outlined in the note. The descriptor file can contain range conditions for multiple CDS Views.

After creating such a file, it must be uploaded to the system via the DHADM UI. During the upload, all ranges will be analyzed for syntax errors. Logical errors in the definition (e.g., overlapping ranges or gap in range conditions) will not be checked and remain with the user! Attention: when uploading ranges, the previous definition will be overwritten. After uploading, you can change and correct the ranges using the built-in UI or by changing the source file to repeat the upload.

If you have defined or corrected ranges in the test system, you can export all ranges to a file and transfer them to the production system.

[
	{
		"cdsviewname": "I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMRAWDATA",
		"ranges": [
			{
				"id": 1,
				"condition": "FiscalYear < '2021'"
			},
			{
				"id": 2,
				"condition": "FiscalYear >= '2021' and FiscalYear < '2022'"
			}
		]
	}
]

Code 3. Example of JSON file for CDS View I_GLAccountLineItemRawData

Upload/Download ranges

Picture 3. Upload or download ranges for one or several CDS Views


Similar to partitions, access plans will be calculated for each range separately. Similar to the option with partitions, the pre-calculation process will also be performed in parallel for each range.
The most important rule: all operations must be performed before the start of the load. Existing subscriptions do not take ranges into account in the pre-calculation process.

entry.title: Re: Error importing data
entry.content:
@Ganjos , Looks like you have Data Access configured on the model. You can check it in Model settings. Check what dimensions are used to define the Data Access. In those dimensions you will have Read and Write column which controls are read and write access to those members of the dimension. The end user does not have access to the members you are loading the data to. You need to ensure the end user has write access to all members you are trying to load the data for in all secured dimensions.

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Deep Link to PCC
entry.content:
Hello, 

there isn't any PCC home page, but you can access each PCC app using a direct link.

The direct link should be built like the following:

https://<host>:<port>/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*>/index.html?sap-client=<client>&sap-ui-language=<language_code>

where:

<host>:<port> : to retrieve that information, you can use trx SMICM: Goto-->Services

/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/<hrpy_pcc_*> : you should indicate the PCC service. See the whole list in the attached link:

Use Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

or

Activate Payroll Control Center SAPUI5 Applications | SAP Help Portal

<client> : client of your system

<language_code> : your preferred language

In addition, you could configure FIORI launchpad (see below link) where you can define specific tile for each PCC service: 

Configure Fiori Launchpad Tiles for Payroll Control Center | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: Welcome SAP-RPT-1! What is it? How can you try it out?
entry.content:
SAP announced SAP-RPT-1 at TechEd 2025 in Berlin. What is it good for, and how can you try it out? In this blog post, I'll walk you through the announcement and show you how to get started, both in a no-code approach and in Python.

 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT stands for Relational Pre-Trained Transformer which SAP wants us to pronounce as 'rapid one'. To make sure this is pronounced correctly, they even write out phonetic transcription [Ààr√¶p…™d] [w ån] - so no excuses here üòâ.

If you are looking for a quick executive summary, check out Philipp Herzig's Keynote presentation which explains that RPT-1 is a new type of AI model that is optimized for making predictions on tabular data. Unlike LLMs which generate the next word (token) for a text sequence, RPT-1 predicts the next field in a table row. Putting this in a practical example, Philipp mentions that RPT-1 can predict, for example, delivery times or customer churn, essentially replacing traditional ML models like XGBoost or Random Forest with a single RPT-1 model.

For now, SAP-RPT-1 comes in 3 flavors:

  • SAP-RPT-1-Small: A small model optimized for super-fast predictions
  • SAP-RPT-1-Large: A larger model optimized for highest accuracy
  • SAP-RPT-1-OSS: An "open source" version for everybody to learn (Github / Huggingface)

The way Philipp talked about the OSS version, I assume that this is also the version which is available in the RPT Playground, your starting point to try out RPT-1 in a no-code environment.

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in the RPT Playground

The easiest way to get started with RPT-1 is the RPT Playground. SAP has prepared some data, but you can also upload your own tabular data (CSV files) and use RPT-1 to make predictions on it. The trick for making predictions with RPT-1 is to mask the field you want to predict with [PREDICT]. Once you click on the "Predict" button, RPT-1 will fill in the masked field with its prediction.

While SAP's prepared use cases work well, you'll get a better sense of RPT-1's capabilities by trying it with your own data. To help you get started, I've prepared the example data from the coding tutorial (allowing you to predict sales groups from Product, Price, Customer, Country) in a CSV file for you to download. You can easily modify this file in Excel (or any other editor), save as CSV and try your own data in the RPT Playground. If you'd prefer to start simple, try out the example CSV file I have prepared for you.

If you're not a coder, simply skip the coding section and jump right to the conclusion.

 
 

Trying out SAP-RPT-1 in Python

If you want to get your hands dirty with code, I have prepared a Jupyter notebook that shows in detail how to use RPT-1.

Prerequisites

Assuming you have access to the RPT Playground and that you have downloaded the Jupyter notebook, you need to fetch your access token from the bottom of the playground page.

To avoid storing your credentials in the notebook, copy & paste the token (RPT_TOKEN) into a .env file in the same folder where you have stored the Jupyter notebook. It should look like this:

RPT_TOKEN="eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1" # truncated, your token is a lot longer

Once you've done that, you're ready to run the notebook.

 
 

Preparing Test Data

Here's the test data in the format RPT-1 expects:

 
payload = {
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [
            {
                "name": "SALESGROUP",
                "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]"
                # "task_type": "classification" or "regression" can be specified here if needed
            }
        ]
    },
    "index_column": "ID",
    "rows": [
        {
            "ID": "1001",
            "PRODUCT": "Tablet",
            "PRICE": 599.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "TechStart Inc",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1002",
            "PRODUCT": "Standing Desk",
            "PRICE": 325.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "Workspace Solutions",
            "COUNTRY": "Germany",
            "SALESGROUP": "[PREDICT]"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1003",
            "PRODUCT": "Workstation",
            "PRICE": 1450.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Enterprise Systems Ltd",
            "COUNTRY": "Canada",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1004",
            "PRODUCT": "Laptop Pro",
            "PRICE": 1899.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Business Corp",
            "COUNTRY": "UK",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1005",
            "PRODUCT": "Gaming Laptop",
            "PRICE": 1250.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Digital Ventures",
            "COUNTRY": "USA",
            "SALESGROUP": "Enterprise Solutions"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1006",
            "PRODUCT": "Smart Watch",
            "PRICE": 299.99,
            "CUSTOMER": "Gadget Store",
            "COUNTRY": "Australia",
            "SALESGROUP": "Consumer Electronics"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1007",
            "PRODUCT": "Ergonomic Chair",
            "PRICE": 445.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "Office Outfitters",
            "COUNTRY": "France",
            "SALESGROUP": "Office Furniture"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1008",
            "PRODUCT": "Storage Array",
            "PRICE": 3500.00,
            "CUSTOMER": "CloudTech Systems",
            "COUNTRY": "Singapore",
            "SALESGROUP": "Data Infrastructure"
        },
        {
            "ID": "1009",
            "PRODUCT": "Network Switch",
            "PRICE": 175.50,
            "CUSTOMER": "ConnectIT",
            "COUNTRY": "Japan",
            "SALESGROUP": "Networking Devices"
        }
    ]
}
 
 

For better readability, here is the data in table format:

 
import pandas as pd

sample_data = pd.DataFrame(payload["rows"])
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
#sample_data.to_csv("sample_data.csv", index=False)
 
 

As you can see, we have 4 attribute columns: Product, Price, Customer, Country. Our target column is the Sales Group. Therefore, the sales group is masked in 2 lines with the value [PREDICT], so that RPT-1 can demonstrate that it can fill in the missing values.

 
 

Running the predictions

To run the predictions, we will use the requests library to send an HTTP POST request to the RPT-1 API endpoint. The request will include our test data and the authorization token.

 
#!pip install python-dotenv # install if not already installed
 
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

load_dotenv()

auth_token = os.getenv("RPT_TOKEN")
 
import requests

url = "https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict"

headers = {
    "Content-Type": "application/json",
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {auth_token}"
}

response = requests.post(url, json=payload, headers=headers)
 
 

Analyzing the results

Let's take a look at the results returned by RPT-1. Here are the predictions in the raw JSON format:

 
import json

data = response.json()
preds = data["prediction"]["predictions"]
print(json.dumps(preds, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False))
 
[
  {
    "ID": 1001,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Enterprise Solutions"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "ID": 1002,
    "SALESGROUP": [
      {
        "confidence": null,
        "prediction": "Office Furniture"
      }
    ]
  }
]
 
 

Let's merge these predictions back into the tabular format to see the results more clearly.

 
preds_df = sample_data.copy(deep=True)

preds_df["ID"] = preds_df["ID"].astype(int)

for pred in preds:
    row_idx = int(pred["ID"])
    predicted_value = pred["SALESGROUP"][0]["prediction"]
    preds_df.loc[preds_df["ID"] == row_idx, "SALESGROUP"] = predicted_value

preds_df
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSAEnterprise Solutions
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermanyOffice Furniture
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

For comparison, here is the original sample data before predictions:

 
sample_data
 
  ID PRODUCT PRICE CUSTOMER COUNTRY SALESGROUP012345678
1001Tablet599.00TechStart IncUSA[PREDICT]
1002Standing Desk325.50Workspace SolutionsGermany[PREDICT]
1003Workstation1450.00Enterprise Systems LtdCanadaEnterprise Solutions
1004Laptop Pro1899.99Business CorpUKEnterprise Solutions
1005Gaming Laptop1250.00Digital VenturesUSAEnterprise Solutions
1006Smart Watch299.99Gadget StoreAustraliaConsumer Electronics
1007Ergonomic Chair445.00Office OutfittersFranceOffice Furniture
1008Storage Array3500.00CloudTech SystemsSingaporeData Infrastructure
1009Network Switch175.50ConnectITJapanNetworking Devices
 
 

Conclusion

As we can see, RPT-1 has filled in the missing sales groups based on the patterns contained in the context, i.e., the other entries. Essentially, the non-masked rows serve as few-shot examples that RPT-1 uses for in-context learning. This behavior is comparable to an LLM imitating examples you provide in a prompt. Here's a simple example of such a prompt:

Write an executive summary for the Lord of the Rings.

Here is an example for Romeo and Juliet:
Boy and girl fall in love, in the end they both die.

If you try this prompt, you might get a result like this:

Guy inherits ring. Walks a lot. Destroys it.

Similarly, RPT-1 uses the non-masked rows as examples to predict the masked values. The key difference is that RPT-1 does not semantically generate text, but it predicts the most likely value for the masked fields based on the patterns it has learned during training.

Of course, the example we used is very simple, and it will be interesting to see how RPT-1 performs on more complex datasets. For now, I hope you are all set to try SAP-RPT-1 with your own data. Happy experimenting!

entry.title: New version 8.6 of the SAP Cryptographic Library with quantum-safe cryptography and FIPS 140-3 mode
entry.content:
Overview

The SAP Cryptographic Library enables applications like SAP S/4 HANA to support security protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security), SNC (Secure Network Communication), SSF (Secure Store and Forward) and X.509. While the library already includes "modern" cryptographic algorithms such as those based on Elliptic Curve Cryptography, these were until now all part of the group of "classic" algorithms. 

Most "classic" algorithms for asymmetric cryptography are vulnerable when a cryptographically relevant quantum computer becomes reality. This might have an impact even today if attackers record encrypted communication and store it for later decryption ("harvest-now-decrypt-later"). 

Quantum-safe cryptography in the SAP Cryptographic Library

The new version 8.6 of the library enables support for a quantum-safe TLS 1.3 handshake. When the library is installed on an SAP NetWeaver ABAP system and TLS 1.3 is used to establish a connection, then a hybrid ECDHE-MLKEM key agreement based on X25519MLKEM768 takes place. ML-KEM is a new, quantum-safe algorithm for key encapsulation, which was already standardized as FIPS-203. This makes it impossible, even for a quantum computer, to determine the session key and decrypt the session communication. 

New FIPS 140-3 certification of the FIPS crypto kernel

FIPS stands for Federal Information Processing Standard. A FIPS certification is required by US public sector agencies, healthcare, and financial industries, and many more. FIPS 140-3 validates the proper implementation of the algorithms in cryptographic modules.

The FIPS crypto kernel is a dedicated module in the SAP Cryptographic Library that was recently certified as compliant with FIPS 140-3. The certificate is available from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST): Certificate #5093.

For SAP Application Server ABAP and SAP HANA, SAP note 2180024 explains the configuration steps that are required to switch the SAP Cryptographic Library to FIPS mode.

Release Details

The release note "3685428 - Fixes and features in CommonCryptoLib 8.6.2" has now been published. More information about the SAP Cryptographic Library is available in "1848999 - Central Note for CommonCryptoLib 8 (SAPCRYPTOLIB)".

entry.title: Re: Hi Experts,I need your guidance. We are working in SA...
entry.content:
Yes, instead of relying on 309 material-to-material transfer, stage-wise SFG inventory updates using production order‚Äìbased postings (movement 261/101) or custom goods receipt processes with batch management is possible, which allow system-generated batches and capture process losses more naturally than 309 transfers. But I am not sure, whether production order creation is possible since your post says not fully configured.

So the work around would be

  • Movement 501 (GR without PO) ‚Üí Create stock for the new material with a fresh batch.
  • Movement 201/202 (issue to cost center) ‚Üí To reflect consumption/loss of input material.

Together, these mimic stage-wise consumption and creation without PP orders.

entry.title: SAP Advanced Financial Closing - definition of Parameters
entry.content:
Hello team,

  • in the documentation of SAP advanced financial closing I read here for Fiori App integration: "During this navigation SAP Advanced Financial Closing also forwards parameters, such as ledger, fiscal year or period, to the SAP Fiori application. The parameter information is taken from the task list."
  • "Such as" leads me to the expectation that I configure the parameters for Fiori Apps somewhere in AFC. So I look into the task list models, task lists and task template definition and find nothing regarding this topic.
  • Then I look into How to Maintain Task Parameters". This description sounds to me that I can define parameters on all levels. Great!
  • Then I find in Parameter Maintenance: "Parameters apply to tasks of the types Job and Workflow that require this particular parameter. During task processing, the parameters are forwarded from SAP Advanced Financial Closing to the corresponding report or workflow and are applied."

So is it now possible to define parameters for Fiori Apps or not? Is it possible to use standard parameters, e.g. variance, for Fiori Apps, or not?

Best regards

Christian

entry.title: Re: Get the price for a material without simulating sales...
entry.content:
The best approach is to:

  1. Build a custom CDS view on condition record tables (Axxx, KONP) for condition type PR00.

  2. Use that CDS in your custom app to fetch prices for multiple materials at once.

  3. If you need full net price (with discounts, freight, taxes), keep BAPI as fallback.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creati...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn

Yes,  grouping relationships involving the same BP into one set of 100 can significantly help avoid the locking conflicts you are currently facing. Considering creation happens in parallel background jobs, if the same BP appears across different parallel jobs, it can easily cause deadlocks or serialization issues, especially since SAP_WFRT attempts to lock and activate those records simultaneously.

Best regards

Chris
